newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EU, ACP states begin shaping new Lome Convention.
newsitem.headline: EU, ACP states begin shaping new Lome Convention.

text.p: The European Union and its main trading partners in the developing world on Saturday wrapped up a two-day meeting in the southern Dutch town of Maastricht with a call for a deepening of economic relations.
"There has been a call for a broader agreement, particularly in the economic field, on the relationship between trade and aid," Dutch Overseas Development Minister Jan Pronk told a news conference.

Political and economic ties between the EU and the seventy African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states, most with colonial ties to EU countries, are enshrined in the Lome Convention, a framework for trade and aid which expires in the year 2000 after 25 years.
The Dutch government, as current EU President, says the convention needs to be amended "because of the essential changes which have taken place on the world stage in the last 10 years."
But some the hottest trade issues facing the two groups remain unresolved.

The European Union's banana regime, which has sparked a war of words between Brussels and Washington is one such case. The regime favours imports from mainly Caribbean countries but was recently found by a World Trade Organisation dispute panel to violate open trading rules.

In an interim ruling the WTO found in favour of a complaint by the United States and four Latin American countries that the EU regime which permits the duty-free import of 875,000 tonnes of ACP-grown bananas discriminated against their companies.
If a final WTO decision goes against the EU, Brussels may have to pay compensation to the United States, Ecuador, Mexico, Guatamala and Honduras for their lost export revenue.
But Pronk said he did not expect the EU to drop its system of granting preferential trade protocols to ACP states.
"I expect there will not be an outcome of negotiations that will lead to the withdrawl of preferences," he said, adding he thought they could be continued in some form within WTO rules.
